comments.commentBody: I think his point is that it's a question asked by fans of teams who live the good life most of the time.  Of course, I do agree the Raiders history as a whole hasn't exactly been a bad one.  And I also seem to remember them making it to the Super Bowl the year after the tuck fiasco.

Tom Brady wasn't a rookie when the Patriots beat the Raiders (he was in his second year), and the Raiders have won multiple Super Bowls since 1972 (not exactly decades of futility).

FYI, the Packers, Giants and Cowboys are three of the most successful franchises in NFL history, which makes this statement absurd:

"Not why do the Raiders keep losing, but why does anyone follow an incompetent, perpetually failing team? It’s a question that resonates across an entire nation of fanatics, from the frigid Cheeseheads of Wisconsin to the yodeling herds of Texas, from the mile-high multitudes to the bellowing masses of New York. "

True but even clean politics requires a critical appraisal of each candidate to determine the most suitable - a leader of integrity, good judgement and character, calm in the face of calamity, honest, fair, astute, wise, courageous, compassionate and capable, with policies that reflect our values. Does Romney meet these qualities? Even the source of wisdom from which you draw those biblical virtues of brotherly love and understanding, says "I lay in Zion, a TRIED stone..." We do need to try and vet the candidates by the only means available to us - their past actions and policies.

It's a tough quandary. I think it is necessary to both critique the opponent and highlight the virtues of the Dems. A delicate balance and no easy
challenge but it's important not to allow R&R safe passage through their smoke and mirrors jam and also essential to accent that the care for the ENTIRE citizenry is being protected by the Democrats. Sadly, I have lost hope that this can be accomplished by simply being reasonable and articulate. Deafness is currently a world wide disease.

Dear Ms. Mo, Piling on Mitt is a kind of tormenting the afflicted.
Honestly, I believe the better strategy pursues the virtues of our position.
I assert that brotherly love and understanding are invincible.
Any examination of flawed actions or policies is beside the point, a distraction, and plays into their hands. Not commercial avarice, but the American principles, reason, equality and liberty present a better angel in our own mirror as well as political debate. Endless attacks are what they do. We can do better.

Douthat says that, because like many in his party, he doesn't like the idea that women are having sex for the sake of sex and not pregnancy. In his mind, a woman who chooses to have sex also chooses to have a baby. He doesn't separate one from the other.

I wonder if he is consistent in this view when it comes to men? If he is consistent, then he should not support the sale of Viagra unless its sole purpose is as a fertility drug (I don't know if Viagra can actually fix old sperm but that's another story). I'd loooove to know his thoughts on this, but, alas, like most Republicans, he will be conveniently quiet on this one I'm sure.
For roughly the last three decades the Thompson article has appeared in philosophy textbooks as the strongest argument for abortion rights.  There is nothing arcane about it, except for you.

The very poll you cite shows 77+% of Americans want abortion legal under some or all circumstances. That would indicate the President's stance on Free Will for women is not "outside" the norm, but represents it very well.

You also state "most women considering an abortion were not kidnapped and impregnated against their will. They freely chose the act that brought the fetus into being, and analogizing their situation to a kidnap victim implies a peculiar, almost infantilizing attitude toward female moral agency."

a) This "thought experiment" is not widely known, and your use of it to illustrate your point ONLY illustrates your point (and therefore why you chose it);

b) how does one "freely choose the act" if one is on birth control that fails? I do recall a certain contraception manufacturer recalling a series of faulty pills that did; if these women did not "freely choose" to become impregnated, could they have sued the manufacturer for rape? (A thought experiment for the next column, perhaps....?)

Finally, you state Mr. Romney's position on abortion is being mischaracterized (actually, you said "accused falsely" by Democrats). Do you presume Mr. Romney will NOT receive the nomination of the party in Tampa? The party's official platform, one which Mr. Romney is obligated to implement, calls for a BAN on abortion, plain and simple... regardless of Mr. Ryan's 'wiggle' when asked directly. He knows very well what's on the agenda - and it is NOT Free Will for women.

Save the talk. All romney and ryan want to do is follow the laffer curve and give the wealthy and corporate a tax break. And we all know that that curve does not mean meaningful jobs for anyone. It has been tried for 30 years in every gop regime. Just more money and power for thiose have money. And while they are at it find another war to start since they both have demonstrated themselves to be neo cons.

He will never discuss anything of substance. That way he can appeal to his base and perhaps in some way bamboozle all of those who have not actually read and considered what the want to do.

They will both continue to etch-a-sketch themselves hoping smoke and mirrors will work. I can't decide if taking it back to the age of the robber barons will be enough. Perhaps the real goal is the ancien regime.Remember romney alnost and america the banana republic.

All sounds good - smaller government, less wasteful Socialist Democrat spending, no bailout bucks wasted on an again failing Government Motors, aborting of Obamacare that is adding $250 Billion in costs per year, less Liberal commie judges, death of Democrats corrupt donation system (aka Unions), no more kowtowing bend-over diplomacy, and end to Welfare (Democrat vote buying plan).

Got anymore reason why we should vote for Romney and not vote for Obama?
He'd open another Guantanamo, or two.  He didn't say for whom.

We can't look into the future and see what Mitt Will do, but we can look back and see what he's done and says he'll do:
- he called for the virtual elimination of the Dept of Agriculture
- he wouldn't have bailed out GM and would have let tens of thousands lose their jobs
- he'd repeal financial regulation
- he'd repeal Affordable Care
- he'd expand the armed forces by 100,000
- he'd ratchet up confrontation with Russia
- he'd enact large portions of Ryan's supply side budget
- he'd appoint more conservative judges if given the chance
- he favors the Citizens United ruling
- he sees labor unions as being bought and paid for by the Democrats
- he'd disband the National Labor Relations Board
- he favored stimulus and condemned it when Obama did it
- he'd continue Bush's tax cuts and make them better for the wealthy and worse for middle class
- he'd replace unemployment but we don't know what with
- he'd "get tough with China"
- having avoided Vietnam himself he'd risk war for his services with Iran

He'll be a president that Grover Norquist, Rush Limbaugh, Karl Rove fans will be proud of.
Can we add global warming to the list now? Please?

Hi Ed,

I'd look back at the history of rocketry on this and say it was longer term than just Apollo. And, there may be a lesson for today on this account. A carbon tariff based trade war might push us to the edge of the possible in terms of dealing with a large problem with similar duration.

Fossil fuel free manufacturing globally would surely be a giant leap for mankind.

The former shuttle astronaut Ed Lu sent this note by e-mail:

Yes, it was a sad today today. I had the great pleasure of speaking to Neil while I was aboard the International Space Station (and he was at the Experimental Aircraft Association's annual fly-in at Oshkosh). Definitely one of my treasured memories.

As to your [son's] question, I suspect that you are right. In most cases I do believe that the nature of our Government requires something short term and urgent in order to undertake something of this magnitude. That being said, when something is considered short term and urgent, we are pretty good at dealing with those types of issues!

Ed

http://edlu.com/

Where are all the OTHER nations??

What are THEY doing to help????

Oh, nothing? I guess they expect this nation, and this President, to jump in and save these children, when they're ALL sitting on their hands.

A pittance to the United Nations for show, and nothing more.

For shame.
Tim B, you beat me to it.

It so happens that karma and mother nature are the 2 things nobody can buy.......even with the all the Money the GOP have.....they will just have an inconvenience but not quite like what the poor, homeless Haitians are currently going through.......no problem, though. It is just the poor and so, ' there it is ' as Romney, Ryan and the rest of their ilk would say with a collective, indecent shrug of those wealthy shoulders.

I don't think you can call a hurricane occurring during hurricane season in hurricane-prone state an example of climate change.

On the other hand, choosing to hold your convention there is a stellar example of poor planning skills.
Talk about perfect karma, the first day of the Republican convention canceled, dare we say due to "climate change"?

"Down To The River To Pray":
(hard times @ 1:52)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2qw6Hon013E&feature=fvwrel

The issue of our species surprising susceptibility to primate dominance hierarchies calls to mind a line from "O Brother Where Art Thou?":
"Hard times flush the chumps."
Good.  One day less of the uber-wealthy patting themselves on the back for the hard work of their underlings.

Governor Christie thinks very small, and very short-term. And he bullies people: reporters, teachers, staff, the public.

UGH.

We already have enough bullies in this nation in power... all those (R) governors cutting and cutting and cutting (and giving bonuses to their staff) and never seeing the impact that has on local schools and communities.

Families in trouble NEED services like better education and training to get OUT of trouble.

Small thinker, small doer. Only the media and the (R) think he's great.

I was working as a stock clerk in a liquor store when Armstrong set foot on the moon. We all stopped working to watch for a few minutes. The store's owner said, "Russia, I hope you're watching this!"

I said nothing, because I didn't want to get fired, but I thought his remark was particularly stupid. Although the space race was sparked by the cold war, the real news is that we (mankind, not the U.S. of A.) got to the moon, fulfilling — just 66 years after Kitty Hawk — humanity's ultimate goal in flight. (A Mars landing couldn't be long in the coming, could it?)

The cold war was going on, sure, but lots of us didn't give a damn about that — only about "one giant leap for mankind."

Still do.

Excuse me? This team was absolutely dominating the majors before having to deal with a series of debilitating injuries (Rodriguez, Teixeira, Swisher, Gardner, Pettitte, Sabathia). At this point, they are still in first place with most of the injured getting ready to return. The team's depth--Chavez and Jones--has been enough to carry them through this stretch. Thank you, Brian Cashman. And the team has been more than ably managed during this tough period. Thank you, Joe Girardi.

And why on earth would anyone want to take away the fabulous home run stats of the four players you want to unload? Texeira: 23 HR, 80 RBI; Granderson: 32 HR, 73 RBI; Swisher: 19 HR, 72 RBI; Cano 25 HR, 68 RBI.

Perhaps they should hire Eliot Spitzer and William Black, former banking regulator during the S&L crisis, who helped identify the Keating Five and senior insiders that resulted in over 1,000 felony convictions.

“We’ve got to stop this dynamic that’s producing recurrent, intensifying crises. This one has devastated the nation. The next one would probably be equivalent to the Great Depression. And part of that answer, but only part of it, is to hold the folks accountable, especially the most elite, who caused this crisis. And they did it through fraud in what we call the ‘C-suites’—the CEOs, the COOs—so the absolute top.”
–William Black, Democracy Now interview
Sorry but this administration seems to prefer to vigorously prosecute/persecute, take your pick, whistleblowers.

The Obama administration declined to prosecute "at this time," citing a lack of proof necessary for indictments, but stated they would re-evaluate should more details come to light.

LET'S HANG OUT THE SIGN: WHISTLEBLOWERS WANTED.

Get them evidence and let's get 'er done.

"If I had my career over again? Maybe I'd say to myself, speed it up a little."

Happy birthday to Will, who is a month younger than I.

Mac

Martin,
Thanks for posting this...and we encourage anyone who wants to post a bday puzzle in Will's honor to do so! The more the merrier!!!!!

I hope Deb won't mind me going off topic a bit, but August 26 is Will Shortz's birthday and this is the big 60. A cabal called the Dirty Half-Dozen has posted a Sunday-sized "gift" (just what WS needs -- another puzzle!) over at Amy Reynaldo's Diary of a Crossword Fiend:
http://www.crosswordfiend.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=17&t=1231

If you want even more, this post is in a thread dedicated to WS "gifts."

The .001% of this world simply don't care. They have the money to buy and sell elections; they have the money to overthrow governments; they have the money to sucker a city mayor into a prima facie "good deal" when they know it "stinks," as one trader succinctly termed it.

They don't care. They just want power, and wealth... the more, the better.

For them.

After all, they're "better" than everyone else... they're the "cream rising to the top."

Time to skim the cream and bottle it up tight so it doesn't spoil the milk.

Hey..Petey..you stole my comment above...but don't worry, I will
temper my anger with moderation....

Everything in moderation. That is the golden mantra. It applies to bikram yoga or anything we become dependent on, Balance is key. Balance also birings contentment. Neither exhilaration nor depression, a state of in between. Receive praise and blame evenly. The middle way.
I've practiced Bikram for more than 10 years. Like anything else, it's not the answer, but it helps.
Beautiful essay! I love the ending especially.

Well..SteveRR..although I agree with you somewhat...let me state the other side.....It will eventually lead to
joylessness but while you are doing it, it is great joy, that is why people
do it.

A classic example of that is Jack LaLanne who never ate a dessert, white bread, anything decadent and bad...He did live to be 95 but I know
friends who smoke, drink, pig out and live to be -70-95.

As the old Red Buttons line went...LaLanne never got a dinner or
at least a savory one.

Bottom line is not to go to either extreme...That is true joy.
The mother of excess is not joy but joylessness. Human, All Too Human (1878)

Great column and a very accurate portrayal of the advantages and disadvantages of practicing Bikram yoga.  I've practiced off and on for 10 years and there are some amazing benefits but there's also a cult-like feel to Bikram that I try not to get caught up in.  Thanks for writing about the dark side so eloquently.  Bikram yoga has its limits, but of course you won't hear about that in the studios.
There's a contradiction in here somewhere, between the past and future versions of Congress.
Splendid show of Right wing integrity, Mr Denial.
"If I had my career over again? Maybe I'd say to myself, speed it up a little."
